this is terrific work on data ethics and critical digital literacy ‚Äì developed by a team with extensive experience in digital & open education, open data and critical approaches. many thanks @jatenas @carolak @leohavemann @c_timmermann #digHEIE https://t.co/IwCdFvBJCT

One big lesson from the 2020 pandemic should be the extreme value of sharing data openly. Countless numbers of excellent PhD theses and investigations have pivoted entirely to analysing open data, unable to collect new. It really underscores how valuable our data is when shared.
Die Deutsche Bahn gew√§hrt Google exklusiven Zugriff auf Echtzeitdaten. Open Data bleibt dabei auf der Strecke. https://t.co/63QibNbGU8

Today spoke to a transit agency MD who told me - " we want startups to use our data, so that passengers benefit". "we want to open data, can you help us ?
I pinched myself to make sure that I am not dreaming.

So my rambling thoughts can be summarized in 3 questions: 1) how can we assure open data would be good quality? 2) how can we understand and uncover biases in open data? 3) how can we prevent that open data lead to more low quality publications?

you find an article in a journal w/ open data policy requiring raw datasets & code.
article didn't upload data. you know there aren't privacy issues w/ data.
you reach out to author who basically says "I'm keeping the data until I publish on it again :)"
how would you handle?
